Explain the difference between AngularJS and Angular (Angular 2+). AngularJS (Angular 1.x) is a JavaScript-based open-source front-end web framework maintained by Google. It uses two-way data binding and relies on controllers for managing application logic. Angular (Angular 2+) is a complete rewrite of AngularJS using TypeScript. It introduces concepts like components, modules, services, and uses a hierarchical dependency injection system. Angular also supports one-way data binding by default and encourages a more component-based architecture. What are Angular components and how do they differ from directives? Angular components are the fundamental building blocks of Angular applications. They consist of a template, which defines the view, and a class, which contains the logic. Components encapsulate HTML, CSS, and business logic into reusable pieces. Directives, on the other hand, are instructions in the DOM that Angular uses to manipulate behavior or appearance. They can be structural (like *ngIf and *ngFor) or attribute-based (like ngClass and ngStyle). While components are typically used for creating reusable UI components, directives are used for enhancing existing DOM elements. Explain Angular Modules (NgModules) and their purpose. Angular Modules (NgModules) are containers for organizing an Angular application into cohesive blocks of functionality. They group related components, directives, pipes, and services together. Modules also enable lazy loading, allowing parts of the application to be loaded on demand. The @NgModule decorator is used to define a module and specify its metadata, including declarations, imports, providers, and exports. What is Dependency Injection (DI) in Angular and why is it important? Dependency Injection (DI) is a design pattern and a core concept in Angular. It allows you to inject dependencies (services or objects) into a class rather than creating them inside the class. DI helps in creating modular, maintainable, and testable code by promoting loose coupling between components. Angular's hierarchical injector system manages the lifecycle of injected dependencies and resolves circular dependencies. Explain the concept of Angular Directives and their types. Angular Directives are instructions in the DOM that tell Angular to manipulate behavior or appearance. There are two main types of directives in Angular: structural directives and attribute directives. Structural directives alter the DOM layout by adding or removing elements based on condition (e.g., *ngIf, *ngFor). Attribute directives change the appearance or behavior of an element, component, or another directive (e.g., ngClass, ngStyle). Directives allow you to extend the HTML vocabulary and create reusable behaviors across components. Discuss the concept of Content Security Policy (CSP) and its role in securing Angular applications. How can you utilize CSP to mitigate risks from Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) and other injection attacks? Enhanced Security with Content Security Policy:  - Content Security Policy (CSP): A security feature that allows developers to define trusted sources for scripts, styles, images, and other resources loaded by the browser.  - Mitigating Injection Attacks: By utilizing CSP, developers can restrict the execution of malicious code from untrusted sources, reducing the risk of XSS and other injection attacks.  - Secure Application Development: - Implementing a well-configured CSP is a crucial step in securing Angular applications and protecting user data from potential vulnerabilities. Angular Template Syntax enables developers to bind data and events between component logic and the DOM. Together, these features facilitate the creation of dynamic and interactive user interfaces. Explain Angular Pipes and their role in transforming data for display. How can you use built-in pipes like DatePipe, CurrencyPipe, and custom pipes for formatting, filtering, and transforming data in templates? Pipes can be chained together and used within interpolation or binding expressions to manipulate data for better presentation. Discuss Angular Internationalization (i18n) and localization support. These testing strategies ensure code quality, prevent regressions, and validate application functionality across different levels. Explain Angular Dependency Injection Hierarchies and scopes. How does Angular manage the hierarchy of injectors, and what are the differences between providedIn and providers array for registering services? Angular Dependency Injection (DI) manages the hierarchical injection of services across an application. Injectors provide instances of services based on their registration scope and hierarchy. providedIn allows services to be registered at the application level or within feature modules, optimizing tree-shaking and reducing bundle size. The providers array registers services at the component level or within NgModule, controlling the scope and lifecycle of service instances. Discuss Angular Performance Optimization techniques. Explain the concept of Dependency Injection (DI) with '@Optional' decorator and its usage for handling optional dependencies within your Angular application. How can you utilize '@Optional' to inject dependencies that might not be present in all scenarios? Explain Angular Forms and their types. How can you implement template-driven forms and reactive forms in Angular applications, and what are the advantages of each approach? Angular Forms are used to capture user input and perform form validation in Angular applications. Template-driven forms rely on directives in the template, while reactive forms are model-driven and managed programmatically using form controls and validators. Template-driven forms are simpler to implement for small forms, whereas reactive forms offer more flexibility and scalability for complex forms and dynamic validations. Services are injected into components or other services using Angular's dependency injection (DI) system, promoting code reusability and maintainability. Best practices include using providedIn for service registration, using singleton pattern for stateful services, and keeping services lean and focused on a single responsibility. Explain Angular Change Detection and its mechanism for updating the DOM based on component state changes. How does Angular detect and propagate changes in the component tree, and what are the performance considerations for optimizing change detection? Angular Change Detection is the mechanism that updates the DOM when the component state changes. Angular uses Zone.js to intercept asynchronous operations and trigger change detection. By default, Angular uses a strategy called dirty checking to detect changes by comparing current and previous values of bound properties. Optimizing change detection involves using ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush to reduce change detection cycles and limiting the use of two-way data binding for better performance. Discuss Angular Pipes and their role in transforming data for display in Angular templates. Custom pipes decorated with @Pipe decorator extend Angular pipe functionality, implementing custom data transformations and filtering logic based on application requirements. Angular Reactive Programming manages asynchronous data streams and event-driven applications using RxJS Observables and operators (e.g., map, filter, mergeMap) for defining and manipulating data streams in Angular applications. Subjects facilitate multicasting and event propagation with multiple subscribers, enabling real-time data synchronization and communication between Angular components and services. BehaviorSubject manages application state and emits the current state to new subscribers, ensuring consistent data access and state management across Angular applications. RxJS operators (e.g., catchError, finalize) handle errors and resource management, enabling robust error handling and resource cleanup in asynchronous data operations and event-driven applications. Jasmine testing framework defines test suites, specs, and expectations for validating Angular application logic and behavior, ensuring functional correctness and code reliability. Spy objects mock dependencies and simulate method calls and behavior in unit tests and integration tests, promoting isolated testing and code coverage in Angular applications. Angular Testing utilities provide helpers and utilities for common testing tasks, facilitating unit test writing and execution in Angular projects. Explain Angular View Encapsulation and its role in isolating component styles and preventing style leakage. How can you use Emulated, None, and ShadowDom view encapsulation modes, encapsulation property in component metadata, and ::ng-deep pseudo-class for managing component styles and encapsulation in Angular applications? Angular View Encapsulation isolates component styles and prevents style leakage using Emulated view encapsulation mode for emulating native Shadow DOM behavior with scoped styles. None view encapsulation mode applies styles globally without encapsulation, enabling global style sharing across components. ShadowDom view encapsulation mode uses native Shadow DOM for encapsulating component styles, ensuring true style isolation and preventing style leakage. Encapsulation property in component metadata configures view encapsulation mode, enabling flexible style management in Angular applications. ::ng-deep pseudo-class penetrates view encapsulation boundaries, applying styles to child components and facilitating complex style customizations in Angular applications. Explain Angular View Encapsulation and its impact on component styles. How can you use Emulated, Native, and None encapsulation modes for controlling style scoping, and Shadow DOM for isolating component styles in Angular applications? Angular View Encapsulation controls how component styles are scoped and applied. Native encapsulation uses the browser's native Shadow DOM to provide true style encapsulation. None encapsulation applies styles globally without any scoping.
